title: Tanzania: Verify Staff Certificates to Curb Cheating
text:
Tanzania: Taifa Stars in Pot Two of 2018 FIFA World Cup Qualifiers 
This was a shame to say the least, to whoever was involved. In May this year, eight employees of the Bank of Tanzania were charged in court for presenting forged documents, showing that they are holders of Certificates of Secondary School Education, issued by the National Examinations Council of Tanzania. 
If this trend goes unchecked, the possibility is that many job hunters or those seeking admission to institutions of higher learning, may use forgery as a shortcut to fill a gap created by their pervious failure to obtain the qualifications. 
Today, more than any time in the history of the country, the demand for job opportunities has by far surpassed available vacancies. Every year, thousands of students graduate from colleges and universities, while many others complete their primary and secondary school education. 
With the stiff job competition, crooks and cheats have also taken advantage of the situation. If no serious measures will be taken, the damage caused by such people may not be easy to repair. 
Forged certificates may be used to fill vacant positions in the medical, pharmaceutical, accounting, engineering, ICT and many such professions requiring highly trained personnel. 
Granted unemployment is one of thorny issues the country is grappling with. Professionalism must not be compromised. In which case, therefore, employers must tighten the noose when conducting any recruitment for new staff. 
And, as a long term strategy, employers might need to verify the certificates of their employees, just to make sure they have the right people holding positions in their organisations. Tanzania
